title: $8M South End penthouse in converted church has views of Prudential Center
author: Regina Cole
bullets: A penthouse in the historic Concord Baptist Church in Boston's South End is listed for $8 million.
The 3,508 sq ft unit includes features like a Great Room, three bedrooms, and elevator access.
Renovated by Kistler and Knapp, the home offers modern amenities, city views, and a historic setting.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 11)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: A one-family Colonial at 56 Valentine Road, Arlington, sold for $2,100,000; built in 1950 with 1,995 sq. ft.
A condo at 1 Nassau St. #1605, Boston, sold for $800,000; built in 2004 with 1,052 sq. ft., 2 bedrooms.
A two-family conventional at 71 Brooks St., Brighton, sold for $1,225,000; built in 1900 with 3,440 sq. ft.

title: Hundreds of students displaced after burst pipe closes UMass Boston dorm
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: A burst sprinkler pipe at UMass Boston's East Residence Hall displaced hundreds of students due to flooding.
About 50 rooms on floors 2-10 suffered water damage; the dorm is closed for repairs, awaiting further assessments.
Temporary housing at UMass Amherst offered to affected students as UMass Boston seeks accommodations closer to campus.

title: Seattle Public Library schools the Boston Public Library with book recommendations for Patriots fans
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Seattle Public Library recommended 35 Seattle-themed books to Boston Public Library after Patriots lost to Seahawks in Super Bowl LX.
Recommendations include Michael Bennett's memoir and a book on inflation, with some humorous nods to the recent football loss.
Both libraries participate in Books Unbanned, supporting teens' rights to read without censorship nationwide.

title: State auditor sues Beacon Hill to force compliance with audit
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: State Auditor Diana DiZoglio sues to enforce a voter-approved mandate to audit the Massachusetts Legislature.
Attorney General Andrea Campbell declined to support DiZoglio's lawsuit, questioning her authority to audit the Legislature.
House Speaker Ronald Mariano and Senate President Karen Spilka are named defendants, resisting the audit mandate.

title: Man arrested in Seaport, charged with human trafficking
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Schineider Dave Macean, 23, was arrested in Seaport during an undercover operation by the Boston Police Department.
Macean faces charges of human trafficking, commercial sex acts, and deriving support from prostitution.
His arraignment is scheduled in South Boston District Court following the sting near Seaport Boulevard and Thompson Place.

title: As Boston residents report daytime coyote sightings, here’s how to stay safe
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Coyotes have been frequently spotted in Boston during their mating season, which occurs from January through March.
Increased coyote sightings are due to natural behaviors, not population growth, says MSPCA-Angell.
MassWildlife advises keeping pets indoors and using hazing techniques if encountering coyotes.

title: Cam Newton reverses course with his comments on Drake Maye after Super Bowl loss
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Cam Newton praised Patriots quarterback Drake Maye for his progress despite previous criticism during the 2025 NFL season.
Maye concluded the season as the MVP runner-up but struggled with turnovers in New England's Super Bowl LX loss.
Newton acknowledged Maye's development and urged him to see the season as a step towards future success.

title: James Hagens wins Beanpot MVP as Bruins prospects thrive in tournament
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: James Hagens won the 2026 Beanpot MVP, aiding Boston College's victory over Boston University with five points in two games.
Hagens, a Bruins prospect, recorded 31 points in 24 games, showing a well-rounded game as a sophomore at Boston College.
Other Bruins prospects Andre Gasseau and Dean Letourneau contributed with goals in BC's win, enhancing Bruins' young talent pipeline.

title: Patriots CB Carlton Davis shares his pitch to free agents ahead of busy offseason
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Carlton Davis is optimistic about attracting new talent after a strong season ending in Super Bowl LX.
New England holds $42.7 million in cap space for potential free-agent signings this offseason.
Patriots seek to leverage recent success to become a favored NFL destination, aided by positive team culture.
